metadata.title: Multitasking | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer documentation page covering multitasking design guidelines across all Apple platforms. The document explains best practices for handling app switching, audio interruptions, background tasks, and platform-specific multitasking behaviors for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and visionOS.

content.text: Multitasking

content.description: Orange rounded rectangle icon representing multitasking. The icon shows a stylized representation of overlapping app windows or layers - appears as a 3D orange/amber colored rounded rectangle shape with subtle depth and layering effect, suggesting multiple stacked interface elements.
content.composition: Single centered icon with 3D perspective showing depth
content.technicalDetails: SF Symbol or custom Apple HIG icon for multitasking pattern
content.contextualRelevance: Visual identifier for the Multitasking section of Apple's Human Interface Guidelines

content.text: Multitasking lets people switch quickly from one app to another, performing tasks in each.

People expect to use multitasking on their devices, and they may think something is wrong if your app doesn't allow it. With rare exceptions — such as some games, and Apple Vision Pro apps running in a Full Space — every app needs to work well with multitasking.
In addition to app switching, multitasking can present different experiences on different devices; see Platform considerations.

A great multitasking experience helps people accomplish tasks in multiple apps by managing content in a variety of simultaneous contexts. Because you don't know when people will initiate multitasking, your app or game always needs to be prepared to save and restore their context.
Best practices

Pause activities that require people's attention or active participation when they switch away. If your app is a game or a media-viewing app, for example, make sure people don't miss anything when they switch to another app. When they switch back, let them continue as if they never left.

boldSections: Pause activities that require people's attention or active participation when they switch away.

content.text: Respond smoothly to audio interruptions. Occasionally, audio from another app or the system itself may interrupt your app's audio. For example, an incoming phone call or a music playlist initiated by Siri might interrupt your app's audio. When situations like these occur, people expect your app to respond in the following ways:

items.text: Pause audio indefinitely for primary audio interruptions, such as playing music, podcasts, or audiobooks.
Temporarily lower the volume or pause the audio for shorter interruptions, such as GPS directional notifications, and resume the original volume or playback when the interruption ends.

content.text: For guidance, see Playing audio.

Finish user-initiated tasks in the background. When someone starts a task like downloading assets or processing a video file, they expect it to finish even if they switch away from your app. If your app is in the middle of performing a task that doesn't need additional input, complete it in the background before suspending.

boldSections: Finish user-initiated tasks in the background.

content.text: Use notifications sparingly. Your app can send notifications when it's suspended or running in the background. If people start an important or time-sensitive task in your app, and then switch away from it, they might appreciate receiving a notification when the task completes so they can switch back to your app and take the next step. In contrast, people don't generally need to know the moment a routine or secondary task completes. In this scenario, avoid sending an unnecessary notification; instead, let people check on the task when they return to your app. For guidance, see Managing notifications.
Platform considerations
Not supported in watchOS.
iOS
On iPhone, multitasking lets people use FaceTime or watch a video in Picture in Picture while they also use a different app.

content.description: iPhone screenshot showing the App Switcher interface. The screen displays a horizontal carousel of app cards/thumbnails representing currently open applications. Multiple app windows are visible as stacked cards that users can swipe through. The interface shows a 3D card-like presentation of each app's last state. Status bar visible at top showing '9:41 Tue Apr 1'. The design uses Apple's modern iOS visual language with rounded corners and subtle shadows on each app card.
content.composition: Horizontal carousel layout with overlapping app cards showing perspective depth
content.technicalDetails: iOS App Switcher accessed via swipe up and hold gesture. Shows app thumbnails with app icons below each card.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates iOS app switching mechanism - the primary multitasking interface on iPhone

content.text: The app switcher displays all currently open apps.

content.description: iPhone screenshot showing Picture in Picture (PiP) mode with a FaceTime call. The main screen displays the Apple Maps app with a map view of the San Francisco Bay Area, specifically showing areas like Los Altos, Antonio Rancho Preserve, San Jose, Stevens Creek County Park, Mountain View, Sunnyvale, Loyola, Cupertino, and Saratoga. A search bar at the top shows 'Search Maps'. At the bottom of the Maps interface is a 'Featured' section showing thumbnail images of destinations including Mount Fuji with 'Learn More' text, and category tabs for 'Asia' and 'Africa'. There's a small floating Picture in Picture window in the corner showing an active FaceTime video call with a person visible in the thumbnail. The status bar shows '9:41 Tue Apr 1' and network indicators showing '2,002' and '11'.
content.composition: Full-screen Maps app with small floating PiP window overlay in corner
content.technicalDetails: iOS Picture in Picture mode. FaceTime window floats above Maps app. PiP window can be moved, resized, or dismissed.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates Picture in Picture multitasking - allowing video calls to continue while using another app

content.text: A current FaceTime call can continue while people use another app.
iPadOS

On iPad, people can view and interact with the windows of several different apps at the same time. An individual app can also support multiple open windows, which lets people view and interact with more than one window in the same app at one time.
People can use iPad with either full-screen or windowed apps. When full screen, apps occupy the full screen, and people can switch between individual app windows using the app switcher.

When using windowed apps, app windows are resizable, and people can arrange them to suit their needs with behavior similar to macOS. The system provides window controls for common tiling configurations, entering full screen, minimizing, and closing windows. The system identifies the frontmost window by coloring its window controls and casting a drop shadow on windows behind it. For guidance, see Windows > iPadOS.
Additionally, videos and FaceTime calls can also play in a Picture in Picture overlay above other content regardless of whether apps are full screen or windowed.

content.label: Note
content.text: Apps don't control multitasking configurations or receive any indication of the ones that people choose.

To help your app respond correctly when people open it while windowed, make sure it adapts gracefully to different screen sizes. For guidance, see Layout and Windows; for developer guidance, see Multitasking on iPad, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro. To learn more about how people use iPad multitasking features, see Use multitasking on your iPad.

content.description: iPad screenshot or illustration showing multitasking with multiple app windows. The image demonstrates the iPadOS windowed multitasking experience where multiple app windows are displayed simultaneously on screen. Windows appear with macOS-style window controls (traffic light buttons) and can be arranged freely. The illustration shows overlapping windows with drop shadows indicating depth and the active window state. This represents the Stage Manager or similar iPadOS multitasking mode where apps can run in resizable windows rather than full screen.
content.composition: Multiple overlapping windows arranged on iPad screen showing depth hierarchy
content.technicalDetails: iPadOS Stage Manager or windowed mode. Shows primary and auxiliary windows with system-provided window controls.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates iPadOS capability to display multiple resizable windows like macOS

content.text: macOS

On Mac, multitasking is the default experience because people typically run more than one app at a time, switching between windows and tasks as they work. When multiple app windows are open, macOS applies drop shadows that make the windows appear layered on the desktop, and applies other visual effects to help people distinguish different window states; for guidance, see macOS window states.
tvOS
On Apple TV, people can play or browse content while also playing movies or TV shows in Picture in Picture (where supported).
visionOS
On Apple Vision Pro, people can run multiple apps at the same time in the Shared Space, viewing and switching between windows and volumes throughout the space.

Only one window is active at a time in the Shared Space. When people look from one window to another, the window they're currently looking at becomes active while the previous window becomes more translucent and appears to recede along the z-axis. Closing an app window in the Shared Space transitions the app to the background without quitting it.

content.label: Note
content.text: When an app is the Now Playing app, closing its window automatically pauses audio playback; if people want to resume playback, they can do so in Control Center without opening the window.

Avoid interfering with the system-provided multitasking behavior. When people look from one window to another, visionOS applies a feathered mask to the window they look away from to clarify its changed state. To avoid interfering with this visual feedback, don't change the appearance of a window's edges.

boldSections: Avoid interfering with the system-provided multitasking behavior.

content.description: Embedded video player with Play button showing visionOS multitasking demonstration. The video thumbnail or player shows the visionOS spatial computing interface with multiple windows floating in 3D space. A circular play button icon is visible indicating the video can be played.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates visionOS window behavior and multitasking visually

content.text: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it. In visionOS, as in macOS, people expect the playback they start in one window to continue while they view or perform a task in another window.

boldSections: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it.

content.text: Be prepared for situations where your audio can duck. Unless an app is currently the Now Playing app, its audio can duck when people look away from it to another app.

boldSections: Be prepared for situations where your audio can duck.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Developer Documentation page for Multitasking design guidelines. Covers best practices for app switching, audio interruption handling, background task completion, and notification usage. Provides platform-specific guidance for iOS (App Switcher, Picture in Picture), iPadOS (windowed apps, Stage Manager, multiple windows), macOS (native windowing), tvOS (PiP support), and visionOS (Shared Space, window focus behavior). Includes related resources, developer documentation links, WWDC video references, and a change log documenting updates from June 2023 through June 2025.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces multitasking as an expected feature across Apple devices, noting rare exceptions like Full Space apps on Vision Pro. Emphasizes the need to save and restore context.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Four key guidelines: (1) Pause attention-requiring activities when switching away, (2) Handle audio interruptions gracefully with pause or duck behavior, (3) Complete user-initiated background tasks, (4) Use notifications sparingly for task completion.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a high-level introduction establishing multitasking as an essential app capability, then provides universal best practices applicable across platforms. It then systematically addresses each supported platform (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS) with specific behaviors and recommendations, noting watchOS exclusion. The document concludes with cross-references to related documentation, developer resources, educational videos, and a change log tracking document evolution.

keyTerms.definition: The ability for users to switch quickly between apps and perform tasks in each, including running multiple apps simultaneously on some platforms
A feature allowing video content or FaceTime calls to play in a floating overlay window while using another app
iOS/iPadOS interface displaying all currently open apps as cards for quick switching
visionOS mode where an app takes over the entire view, preventing other apps from running alongside
visionOS default mode where multiple apps can run simultaneously with windows and volumes throughout the 3D space
iPadOS mode where apps run in resizable, movable windows similar to macOS behavior
Temporarily lowering audio volume when another audio source needs attention, then restoring original volume
System designation for the currently active media playback app, which receives special audio handling
System-provided buttons for tiling, full screen, minimize, and close operations on iPadOS windows
visionOS visual effect applied to unfocused windows to clarify their inactive state

keyFindings: Every app should support multitasking with rare exceptions (some games, Full Space apps on Vision Pro)
Apps must save and restore user context because multitasking can occur at any time
Audio interruptions require different handling: indefinite pause for primary audio, temporary duck for short interruptions
User-initiated background tasks should complete even when app is not in foreground
Notifications should only be sent for important/time-sensitive task completion, not routine tasks
iPadOS supports both full-screen and windowed app modes with macOS-like behavior in windowed mode
Apps do not control or receive indication of multitasking configurations users choose
visionOS uses gaze-based focus to determine active window with visual feedback via feathering
visionOS video playback should continue when users look away, unlike attention-based content

designDecisions.decision: Pause attention-requiring activities on app switch
designDecisions.rationale: Users should not miss content when switching away from games or media apps

designDecisions.decision: Indefinite audio pause vs temporary duck
designDecisions.rationale: Primary audio (music, podcasts) should pause completely for other primary audio; short system sounds only need temporary volume reduction
Users expect initiated tasks like downloads to finish regardless of app foreground state

designDecisions.decision: Do not pause video on gaze change in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: Matches macOS behavior where window video continues playing when viewing other windows

designDecisions.decision: Do not modify window edge appearance in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: System applies feathered mask for focus feedback; custom edge styling would interfere

designDecisions.decision: Apps adapt to screen sizes, not control multitasking
designDecisions.rationale: Users choose their preferred multitasking configuration; apps should respond gracefully
